title: What is a hung parliament and what happens to Brexit if the UK gets one?
text:
Brexit will be the most pressing topic as parties try to win over voters (Picture: Getty)

As Brits prepare to head to the polls on December 12, where each party stands on leaving the European Union will be at the forefront of most voters’ minds.

Some, including Labour MP Jess Phillips, have called the General Election a ‘Brexit referendum’, but former Green Party leader Caroline Lucas doesn’t think it will provide much clarity.

But what happens to the UK’s relationship with the EU if there is a hung parliament and no party comes out as a clear winner?

With MPs wading into so much uncharted territory at such a pivotal time in the nation’s history, the answer is unlikely to be clear cut.

Speaking in the Commons yesterday before voting on whether to hold a general election, Ms Phillips said no one could give her an answer when she asked the question.

What is a hung parliament and what happens if there is one?

The Tories are ahead in the polls for now, but there’s a chance no one will win a majority (Picture: Getty)

A hung parliament is when no single political party wins enough seats in a general election to secure a majority of seats in Parliament.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Also known as a situation of no overall control, it makes it significantly harder for the Government to get legislation passed by the Commons and indicates no clear mandate from the people.

Whoever was prime minister before the election will stay in charge and will have to negotiate with other parties to form a coalition, or to try and soldier on with a minority government.

Alternatively they can resign, usually after failing to negotiate a coalition, and effectively pass the burden of deciding what to do to the competition.

The outgoing PM can recommend that the leader of the largest opposition party be invited by the Queen to form a minority government or forge a coalition of their own.

What are the odds of a hung parliament?

Theresa May didn’t expect to lose her majority either when she called an election in 2017 (Picture: AP)

If the polls are anything to go by, the Conservative Party is a fair bit ahead of Labour and the Lib Dems and Johnson is likely to secure a majority.

But anything is possible and, as Ms Phillips pointed out yesterday, the PM’s predecessor Theresa May did not expect to lose her majority back in 2017.

She said: ‘We did not think we were going to be here before, yet here we are.

‘I believe the right hon. Member for Maidenhead thought that she would be having a considerably nicer time when she was next to Lord Buckethead on the evening of the general election, yet here we are.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

According to Ladbrokes, the odds are 11/10 for no overall majority, while the chances of a Conservative majority are not far off at 10/11, with 1/6 changes of having the most seats.

This compares to 16/1 odds of Labour winning more than half of the Commons and a 5/1 chance they will gain the largest number of constituencies.

Why is Boris Johnson holding a general election anyway?

Johnson hopes an election will finally resolve the Brexit deadlock (Picture: PRU/AFP/Getty)

The Prime Minister hopes December’s vote will restore the the Conservative majority lost by Theresa May to end the three years deadlock in the Commons over the UK’s future relationship with the EU.

He said yesterday: ‘We are left with no choice but to go to the country to break free from this impasse, and to allow us all to submit, as we must in all humility, to the judgement of the electorate—to allow us to make our case and, above all, to allow a new and revitalised Parliament, with a new mandate to deliver on the will of the people and get Brexit done.

‘There is only one way to get Brexit done in the face of this unrelenting parliamentary obstructionism, this endless, wilful, fingers-crossed, ‘not me, guv’ refusal to deliver on the mandate of the people, and that is to refresh this Parliament and give the people a choice.’

After the Commons voted against a three-day timetable to railroad his withdrawal deal through Parliament in just three days, Johnson’s pledge to the people to get Brexit done by October 31 ‘do or die’ was scuppered.

Advertisement

Speaking in Parliament yesterday, Ms Phillips said: ‘This is going to be a Brexit referendum whether we like it or not, except that we will not be being clear and we will not be being honest—none of us will be—and in what we get back we will be able to see whatever we want to see.

What will happen to Brexit if there is a hung parliament?

Labour MP Jess Phillips says this general election will essentially be a Brexit referendum but not as clear cut (Picture: PA)

This is probably the question with the least clear answer – but whatever happens, it is likely to lead to yet more political deadlock.

Progress on the WAB has been abandoned for now as Parliament is expected to dissolve on November 6 to make way for election campaigning.

Having extended Article 50 until the end of January, the EU has taken no-deal Brexit is now off the table until then at least, whatever happens after December 12.

Johnson’s Withdrawal Agreement Bill (WAB) received a healthy majority when it was voted for by the Commons last week, so it could still pass if the Tories are the largest party.

But, as ever in politics, it all depends on the numbers, and a minority government will raise plenty of questions over the mandate for Johnson’s deal.

European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker ruled out re-negotiation when Theresa May was still in power, but the bloc ended up budging (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

The European Union has indicated it is not prepared to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement.

Advertisement

But then again, the EU said there wouldn’t budge on Theresa May’s deal, so some wriggle room could be found after the election if Parliament doesn’t get its act together by February.

If no solution has been reached by then, Parliament might have choose between Johnson’s deal, no deal at all, asking for yet another extension to try and forge another agreement.

Alternatively they could cancel Brexit by revoking Article 50 – which is extremely unlikely unless the Lib Dems come to power – or hold another referendum, which would require more time in the European Union to organise.

The bloc still sees a no-deal Brexit as an outcome that will cause serious economic damage for everyone involved.

So as much as they want to avoid it, they are likely to find a way to extend the UK’s membership – but this will hang on whether Government asks for it.

description: General election 2019, set for December 12, will be centred around Brexit, but what happens to the EU deal if there is a hung parliament?
